title: volunteer plea for community companions
story: Royal Voluntary Service is looking for volunteers to become Community Companions, a scheme which offers practical support to older people in Inverurie.Tracey Peden, Community Development Operations Manager at Royal Voluntary Service said: “We are initially looking for one or two volunteer coordinators and volunteers to support the scheme in Inverurie, but there is scope to develop the Community Companions service across Aberdeenshire.“Our volunteers find they get as much out of volunteering as they put in it’s incredibly rewarding for them and they make a real dference to the lives of the people they support.“Those who sign up can choose to dedicate as much or as little time to volunteering as they like and full training will be given.”Community Companions volunteers offer the practical help that can make all the dference to older people and help them retain their independence– from assisted shopping and activity programmes, to enabling them to get out and about with community transport. Volunteers also provide company and companionship, while making sure the older person is safe and well.Royal Voluntary Service is one of Britain’s largest volunteering charities with over , volunteers supporting thousands of people each month in hospitals, at home and in the community.To find out more about becoming volunteer call   or email tracey.hann@royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett, Shaun McCabe, PC Derek Jackson and Lauren McCreedy of Network Rail"  Driving voucher win for Inverurie pupil viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . We are keen to hear what worked and what didn’t last year to help us shape our plans for .”If you can’t make the events you can still provide feedback to yourbusmatters@bususers.org.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. It’s also about learning from others and exploring practice further afield and deciding what to stop doing, what we should be doing more of and what we should start doing.Delegates will take part in a range of workshops and hear from keynote speaker Dave Clubb. Dave who hails from Shetland is a Social Worker with  years experience in dferent positions within the Shetland Islands Council before working for five years on a freelance basis and becoming a foster carer. vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable repairs completed
story: Repairs to a faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, have been completed and the cable has been put back into use.SSEN have said the cable was put back into service on Sunday evening and has been under normal operation since then.Prior to repairs being completed at Rackwick Bay, Hoy, a spokesman from the energy company said an investigation had shown the damage to be located at a section of the Pentland Firth East cable, near the shore at Rackwick.The spokesman said there was no impact to their customers as a result of the fault and contingency measures were put in place.SSEN also reported that, as part of its subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is at #an advanced stage of development#, with cable installation and commissioning due to take place in autumn next year.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: team appointed for 4 5m north isles landscape partnership scheme
story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle swimming pool is not yet sunk say supporters
story: DETERMINED campaigners fighting for a swimming pool dedicated to a fast-growing area of Ross-shire have succeeded in a last-ditch bid to keep the dream alive.The Ross-shire Journal last November told how activists behind a -year drive to establish a pool serving the Black Isle issued an appeal to a new generation to either take the plunge and get involved or see it wound up.The Black Isle Swimming Pool Foundationhas raised more than pound, and won planning approval for a new-build in Fortrose next to the existing leisure centre and secondary school.With anumber of BISPF stalwarts no longer able to continue driving the project, chairman Roy Sinclair appealed to Black Islers to grasp the nettle or wind up the foundation.A make-or-break project strategy meeting in Fortrose has seen a fresh commitment to push forward with a number of avenues to be investigated. These include:* A possible community buyout of the Black Isle Leisure Centre run by High Le Highland for Highland Council.* Appointing a business consultant to update the  business plan and probe funding applications.* Appoint a design team by competitive tender to revise the building plans and invite tenders.It was noted that the Black Isle remains a growing area with future housing and an expanding population.While a lottery bid for pound million towards the estimated poundm cost of the scheme failed back in , negotiations with the Scottish Land Fund via Highlands and Islands Enterprise to consider developing the project as a community enterprise company have continued.Mr Sinclair said: "A unanimous positive attitude was evident at the meeting which allows further progress to be made to develop this very important project for the benefit of folk on the Black Isle and beyond."A follow-up meeting is planned later this month.Whats your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupSaturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall sale brings lots of joy to charities
story: CHARITIES which help Highland cancer patients in their time of need will share a pound, windfall from a special auction in Dingwall.The event at Dingwall Auction Mart had originally been put together to raise funds for Beauly mother-of-two Roz Paterson who had been aiming to secure pound, to fund potentially le-saving treatment in the United States,Her condition has proved resistant to several forms of chemotherapy leaving her facing a race against the clock to try and access expensive Car-T cell therapy in Boston.When it emerged that her treatment will now be funded on the NHS much closer to home, a decision was taken that the mart auction would go ahead ndash with four key Highland charities benefiting instead.Supporters of the Raising for Roz campaign had come up trumps with more than  lots put forward.The go-ahead for the auction provided a welcome boost for Highland Hospice, Marie Curie, MacMillan Nurses and Maggiersquos Highland.The star lot was a wedding package worth pound, which was snapped up by Inverness couple Alison Ireland and Christian Kenway for pound.Auction organiser Willie Matheson hailed the full-house auction a great success. He said: ldquoThe star lot was the wedding package which was quite unique and went to a local girl. That meant a lot to us and a lot to me especially.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwalls Nordic past to live again through trail
story: VIKING culturersquos key role in Dingwallrsquos history could soon be highlighted by a long-awaited heritage trail around the town ndash thanks to the efforts of enterprising residents.The Dingwall Community Development Companyhas already enjoyed considerable but muted success as the recently formed group continues to build membership and go after funding.So far DCDC has funnelled pound of cash from the Gough Charitable Trust to revamping the seating and paths at popular Ferry Point on the shores of the Cromarty Firth. But after holding the first AGM last week, the group now wants to go after larger projects through the lottery funding.The ultimate ambition is to renovate Dingwall Town Hall and ensure it is brought into regular and sustained use by locals and visitors as a focal point of the town.Before that, the DCDC directors and trustees, comprising Janet Bowen, Debbie Downie, Robin Lingard and Nigel Greenwood have been ldquosting through the communityrsquos suggestions for improvements to the town.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoDingwall is very fortunate to have a number of organisations which are dedicated to making the town an attractive and welcoming place. But we want to use our charitable status to unlock funding for capital projects which should make a signicant dference in raising Dingwallrsquos profile.The first of those projects out of the traps has been developed with the help of the Dingwall History Society and is a heritage trail around the town which stops off at around a dozen sites.Among them are the memorial next to the train station, the birthplace of MacBeth ndash Dingwall Castle, as well as the Macdonald Monument and others.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoUsing a series of display  to highlight to both local people and visitors the richness of Dingwallrsquos history, especially as a Viking settlement.A sticking point however is that the bridge over the Dingwall canal is closed due to safety concerns.ldquoThe big issue here, of course, is the future of the footbridge across the Dingwall canal, which has been out of use for some time now because of safety fears. The community council is very anxious to bring it back into use and we are looking at what role we might play in helping to bring it back into use.Many local groups feel that Dingwallrsquos Viking heritage has been a little neglected but in  archaeologists and historians managed to flesh out the legends. They confirmed that the townrsquos Cromartie car park was the site of a Viking parliament or meeting place ndash called a lsquoThingwallrsquo ndash from which Dingwall get its name.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland seafood firm goes into liquidation
story: A Highland seafood firm set up by an award-winning entrepreneur has gone into voluntary liquidation.Coast and Glen, founded by Magnus Houston in , had grown rapidly in recent years, supplying fresh fish and game to hotels and restaurants across the UK and had also expanded direct sales to consumers.The business, which employed nine people and had a turnover of pound. million, operated from fully-fitted leased premises in Alness and had also acquired a new  sq ft factory in Muir of Ord.Its liquidation was attributed to unsustainable cash flow problems stemming from rising costs, intense competition and very low margins.Mr Houston, a former motorcycle racer, taught himself the trade after a bad crash.His other business, Fishbox, is unaffected.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: MSP issues plea over Ross shire rail reliability
story: RELIABILITY issues and a lack of investment are hampering the rail network in Ross-shirersquos ability to capitalise on growing passenger demand, an MSP has warned.Kate Forbes, who represents Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, has called for greater investment after annual passenger figures revealed mixed fortunes for some stations amid a general rise in overall use.Passenger numbers at a number of Ross-shire stations have risen in the past year, with the likes of Dingwalland Kyleamong the big winners.But commuter villages like Beauly and Conon Bridge posted drops of around . per cent ndash amid continuing complaints over train cancellations or services failing to stop when attempting to claw back lost time.And campaigners have been pressing for years for the reintroduction of a section of double track at Lentran between Clachnaharry swing bridge and Beauly station to tackle the issue.Ms Forbes said: ldquoPublic transport needs to be reliable, comfortable and regular. If we want to increase these figures more, ScotRail need to provide more reliable services and a better timetable on the north Highland line ndash especially for those commuting for work.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents asked to play their part in dealing with Alness disorder
story: PARENTS in an Easter Ross town are being asked to ensure they know what their children are up to at night following spates of antisocial behaviour which has spurred a fresh police crackdown.Officers say they have spoken to a number of young people in Alness in the presence of their parents following the incidents, which have also prompted an appeal from a local councillor.Police Scotland Easter Ross community policing Inspector Jamie Wilson said: ldquoI would like to thank the local community for their patience whilst we investigate these incidents.ldquoI appreciate that behaviour of this nature is alarming, however I would like to reassure local residents that we are working closely with schools, High Le Highland and partners to reduce and prevent further antisocial behaviour.ldquoWe continue to investigate incidents which have been reported and are following positive lines of enquiry. Those involved will be identied and will either be reported to the procurator fiscal or issued with a Recorded Police Warning as appropriate.ldquoWe will also be issuing parents with antisocial behaviour letters highlighting the conduct of their children in the hope that they may be a positive influence before things escalate.ldquoOver recent weeks we have spoken with several youths regarding their conduct in the presence of their parents. In the main the response has been positive and I would appeal to parents in Alness to support the community by knowing what their children are doing each evening. We will continue to target our resources in the area to address the behaviour of those involved.Backing police action, Councillor Pauline Munrosaid: ldquoThese incidents have caused concern to local residents, particularly where property has been damaged.ldquoI would urge parents to be aware of what their children are up to during the evenings and to discuss where they are going.Nicky Grant, head teacher at Alness Academy, said: ldquoWe are working in partnership with Police Scotland to ensure that our students and parents feel supported, informed and engaged at this time.Anyone with information should contact Police on  or Crimestoppers on  you would prefer to remain anonymous.Back in November, we reported how youth workers in Alness had appealed to people to share concerns with them and also appealed to parents.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Stone
story: Highlighting the "great historic good" the European Structural Fund has brought to Ross-shire, Easter Ross MP Jamie Stone said: "It paid for new airports, roads, economic development and tourism.ldquoWhen I asked the Prime Minister what would replace this she referred me to the Shared Prosperity Fund. We are very scant on the details of a Shared Prosperity Fund."Could I respectfully ask the Prime Minister to ask officials to meet with myself and other interested members of parliament to discuss what this fund might be and how it might apply to areas of the UK such as my constituency.Mrs May said she is currently in the process of consulting on the nature of the Shared Prosperity Fund and the criteria within which it will work "so I will ask relevant officials to meet with the honourable gentleman in the way he has requested",Mr Stone though said afterwards: "It is clear that there is nothing concrete about a Shared Prosperity Fund. This was the third time I have asked for details on the proposed replacement funding and for the third time I have not received an answer."The Highlands cannot rely on hypothetical funding and Theresa Mayrsquos lack of clarity shows she is aware leaving the EU will make my constituency worse off.ldquoThis comes as it is estimated that the Highlands and Islands would have been entitled to approximately pound million in EU funding between -.ldquoLeaving the EU, particularly crashing out as Theresa May seems to be advocating, would be a disaster for my constituency."I am elected to represent my constituentsrsquo interests and given the shortfall in funding that the Highlands would face in the case of Brexit, I cannot support anything that will make them worse off.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-group, leave a comment or write to us at the address on our letters page.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: no uk clarity on post brexit funding for devolved nations say scots and welsh ministers
story: The UK Government has failed to give clarity on funding for the devolved nations post-Brexit, according to the finance secretaries of Scotland and Wales.Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss spoke to Scotland’s Finance Secretary Derek Mackay and Welsh Finance Minister Rebecca Evans at a meeting in Cardf on Friday.Following the meeting, Mr Mackay said no reassurances were given over the replacement of EU funding or public-sector pensions.Mr Mackay said: “I raised a number of issues with the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, including urging her to rule out a no-deal Brexit, giving me a cast-iron guarantee that all lost EU funding would be replaced in full and meeting all costs associated with the UK Government’s changes to public sector pensions. She could do none of these.• : Theresa May’s Brexit deal suffers a blow as MPs inflict another defeat“With just weeks to go until the planned EU exit day, the Scottish Government remains deeply concerned about the lack of detail regarding replacement arrangements for EU funding streams, not to mention the severe impact a no-deal could have on our economy and labour market.“As a responsible Government, we will continue to intensy our work to prepare for all Brexit outcomes as best we can and press the UK Government to rule out no-deal Brexit and extend the Article  process.”The UK is set to depart from the European Union on March  but no deal has yet been agreed.A deal put forward by Prime Minister Theresa May has failed to gain the support of MPs across the House in Parliament.Welsh Finance Minister Rebecca Evans also suggested the UK Government had provided no reassurances to quell Brexit uncertainty.“I was hoping for much greater clarity on what are becoming very important and pressing issues the closer we get to EU exit day but, disappointingly, I am leaving the meeting no more reassured,” she said.• : Brexit: No one should be ‘hung from a lamp post’ – Ayesha Hazarika“There seems to be a real lack of clarity across the UK Government on what is happening with Brexit but with the very real prospect of a no-deal, this is a huge concern to Welsh Government.“Along with my Scottish counterpart, I pressed the Chief Secretary for clarity on a number of financial issues relating to the impact of Brexit, including the possibility of an emergency budget.“The message was clear, a full fiscal event is not on the agenda, adding to the uncertainties we are facing as we prepare to exit.“The Welsh Government will continue to make the case for Wales to ensure that the interests of Wales are very much at the forefront of discussions.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit no one should be hung from a lamp post ayesha hazarika
story: As arguments over Brexit rage, the tide of online hatred is starting to inundate real-le public discourse with women a particular target, writes Ayesha Hazarika.I always love a trip to Glasgow. Especially for the old banter with the black cab drivers which tends to be much funnier and lighter than the usual London rant about Brexit and Sadiq Khan.On my way to Glasgow airport last week, I was chatting away to a very nice driver who had been nothing but charming until we started talking about politics. Iasked him what he thought of our political leaders.“Alex Salmond – chancer. Nicola Sturgeon – chancer. Jeremy Corbyn – clown. And as for that Gina Miller – I want to see her hung and swinging from a lamppost ... stupid bitch.” It all went a bit quiet after that.This type of aggression is not just on the rise, but it’s part and parcel of how we discuss our politics. You can’t just disagree with someone. You can’t debate policies or ideas using facts, evidence or history. No. You have to call them thick, evil, demonise them, then call them a traitor.It also helps to find something really personal about them or their family to attack them about – their race, religion, gender, sexual orientation, appearance or disability. Demanding they go home is also good one. And the icing on the cake is a physical threat of some kind.: Tory MP accuses police of ignoring abuse aimed at politiciansIt helpsit’s a woman you’re attacking, as you can always terrorise her with sexual violence like a rape threat or good old-fashioned murder. Welcome to Britain in . Don’t you feel a warm glow  I read vile things online on a daily basis. About myself and about other female politicians, writers and pretty much any woman in the public eye with an opinion.But it feels like there’s a level of menace which risks moving from our screens into real le – as we saw with the murder of Jo Cox in  by a right-wing extremist.Women of all political stripes get abuse. Diane Abbott is the most targeted female politician and most of her abuse is violent, racist and sexist. Anna Soubry was physically intimidated and abused outside Parliament by protesters because of her stance on opposing Brexit.The same men also threatened left-wing commentator Owen Jones. A man was arrested earlier this month for alleged death threats against Yvette Cooper.: Brexit: ‘Nazi’ slur is dangerous for democracy – leader commentAnd of course, we have seen the shameful anti-semitic and political abuse of Jewish MP Luciana Berger, which has resulted in three men being jailed for threats in separate cases over the last three years. One sent her a message saying she “would get it like Jo Cox”.And it’s not just high-profile MPs. Female councillors are also subject to harassment and often don’t feel safe during their surgeries. Recent research from Sheffield University found that online abuse of MPs more than doubled between  and .I get that people are engaged, passionate and indeed furious about a whole range of political, economic and social issues from Brexit to austerity to Scottish independence.It’s good for people to care about issues, but we are also becoming a country which can only seem to communicate in ways which are hateful, venal and aggressive.And what becomes normalised online risks bleeding into real le, especiallyyou’re a woman with a view. And that scares me, as it should us all.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scottish government blocks release of nicola sturgeon letter about salmond investigation
story: The Scottish Government has blocked the release of a letter from Nicola Sturgeon to the nation#s top civil servant about its investigation into Alex Salmond, on the basis that it would prejudice his trial.The First Minister wrote to Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans on  June last year, two months after her predecessor told her he was being investigated over allegations of harassment.In her letter she is understood to have told Ms Evans she was aware of the inquiry and that Mr Salmond may be about to launch legal proceedings against the government.Ms Sturgeon was first told about the investigation by Mr Salmond on  April at a meeting at her house in Glasgow. She then spoke to him again on the phone on  April.• : No record of controversial Alex Salmond-Nicola Sturgeon meetingHer letter to Ms Evans, which has never been published, was sent the day before she had another meeting with her predecessor as SNP leader ahead of the party’s conference in Aberdeen.In response to a Freedom of Informationrequest submitted by i, the Scottish Government said releasing the text of the letter risked prejudicing Mr Salmond’s ongoing criminal trial.Last month the former First Minister was charged with  offences including two attempted rapes and nine sexual assaults, which he strongly denies. The date for the next hearing has yet to be set.Mr Salmond also denied the harassment allegations being investigated by the Scottish Government prior to the announcement of the criminal charges.Judicial reviewThe former First Minister won his judicial review against the Scottish Government over its handling of the complaints, after a judge ruled its inquiry had been “tainted by apparent bias”.The FoI request was submitted by this newspaper to the Scottish Government on  January, after Mr Salmond won his judicial review and a week before he was charged by prosecutors.The official response said publication was being blocked because “disclosure would, or would be likely to, prejudice substantially the administration of justice”.It added: “The disclosure of some information could prejudice court proceedings.“We recognise that there is some public interest in disclosing information as part of open, transparent and accountable government, and to inform public debate.“However, this is outweighed by the substantial public interest in ensuring that the courts in Scotland can operate without trials being prejudiced.“In our assessment, release of this information could prejudice a case currently in court in Scotland.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: stephen jardine named presenter of question time style show on new bbc scotland channel
story: The Scotsman columnist, who is currently a regular presenter on BBC Radio Scotland, will be at the helm of Debate Night, an hour-long show which will go on air each Wednesday at .pm.The BBC has also revealed that the show, which will launch on  February, will initially be broadcast from Edinburgh before going out on the road to towns and cities across Scotland.Channel chiefs have given the green light for an initial run of  episodes of Debate Night - which is being launched against a background of controversy over the selection of audiences for Question Time when it is made in Scotland.Debate Night is being made by the same production company, Mentorn Media, which said it was looking forward to working with Jardine to "get Scotland talking" about the new programme.Jardine, who has previously worked as a reporter and presenter for GMTV and STV, said he hoped the new show would be "a great forum for Scotland to share views and opinions in an open and civilised way."He added: "At this time in particular, Scotland should have a programme bringing politicians and the people together and that is what I want this to be. It is a privilege and a responsibility to be tasked with such a big show."Tony Nellany, manager of the new BBC Scotland channel, said: "One of the key aims of the channel is to produce content that will engage our audiences and give them a say on the big issues of the day."Debate Night will do just that under the expert stewardship of Stephen whose authoritative and inclusive presenting style is ideally suited to this format."Nicolai Gentchev, director of current affairs at Mentorn Media, said: "ldquoAt a time when opinion is everywhere, especially on social media, the best way to test ideas is through debate."This is such an exciting time to launch a national debate series. We look forward to working with Stephen to make Debate Night the programme that gets Scotland talking."©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: first look at the jarls squad
story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. The axes are special too with the axe head crafted out of Damascus steel.Mr Nicolson was looking forward to the day ahead, saying: #It is brilliant to get here today and see everybody together. It has been a long couple of years designing the suit and then getting it together.#Plenty will agree that the hard work has been worthwhile.• Don#t miss Friday#s newspaper for the best and most comprehensive coverage of Up-Helly-A#. raquo..

title: council adjourns decision on viking energy
story: A meeting to determine whether the council will object to an application to increase the size of the turbines which would form the Viking Energy windfarm has been adjourned amid confusion among members.The firm is seeking permission to increase the height of the proposed  turbines by  metres to a maximum of  metres.The Scottish government will have the final say on whether the project goes ahead but councillors met on Wednesday afternoon to discuss whether the local authority would, as a formal consultee, object to the application.Councillors expressed dismay saying that it was unclear which new or modied conditions were being considered. Those matters already determined in  and  were not under the microscope.Lerwick South councillor Cecil Smith said that he also felt uncomfortable that this decision was being taken by the council#s planning committee, with just a handful of members present, as opposed to the full council.However, he was informed that a decision had to be made within  hoursthe council were to fulfil its duty as a statutory consultee.Meanwhile, Shetland South member George Smith said that he wanted a new report brought before the council which made it clear what specic issues were relevant to the ied consent application.Councillor Catherine Hughson asked whether an extension could be granted to allow the council further time to consider its response.The meeting was adjourned to allow the council#s corporate services executive manager Jan Riise to seek clarity on this issue.. raquo Let us be very careful about what we approve, for an astonishingly beautul wilderness.Alan SkinnerI too am worried about the finance of all of this. What price are they going to bid in the CFD auction One which is too high and they don#t win One which is too low and actually ends up not viable  Who  is bidding It was the SIC who passed the Viking Energy project to SCT.Does the SCT trust deed allow for further investment in VE If it does then surely it will allow SCT to invest in other capital projects such as tunnels to the isles ..
